0: The Columbia’s 28th space mission, designated STS-107, was originally scheduled to launch on January 11, 2001, but was delayed numerous times for a variety of reasons over nearly two years. Columbia finally launched on January 16, 2003, with a crew of seven. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Eighty seconds into the launch, a piece of foam insulation broke off from the shuttle’s propellant tank and hit the edge of the shuttle’s left wing. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Did You Know? During the 30-year space shuttle program, 355 astronauts traveled aboard the shuttle. The program’s five shuttles (Columbia, Challenger, Discovery, Atlantis, Endeavour) flew more than 542 million miles. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Cameras focused on the launch sequence revealed the foam collision but engineers could not pinpoint the location and extent of the damage. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Although similar incidents had occurred on three prior shuttle launches without causing critical damage, some engineers at the space agency believed that damage to a wing could cause a catastrophic failure. NEWLINE_CHAR NEWLINE_CHAR Their concerns were not addressed in the two weeks that Columbia spent in orbit because NASA management believed that even if major damage had been caused, there was little that could be done to remedy the situation. launches NEWLINE_CHAR
